description: If the second proposal is correct, the term is cognate with Low German trekken, Middle High German trecken, trechen, Danish trække, and Old Frisian trekka, Romanian truc and other Romance languages.
Compare track, treachery, trig, and trigger.

entries.meaning: Involving trickery or deception.
examples: trick photography

entries.meaning: Able to perform tricks.
examples: A trick pony

entries.meaning: Defective or unreliable.
examples: a trick knee

entries.meaning: (chiefly US, slang) Stylish or cool.
examples: Wow, your new sportscar is so trick.

entries.meaning: Something designed to fool or swindle.
examples: It was just a trick to say that the house was underpriced.

entries.meaning: A single element of a magician's (or any variety entertainer's) act; a magic trick.
examples: And for my next trick, I will pull a wombat out of a duffel bag.

entries.meaning: An entertaining difficult physical action.
examples: That's a nice skateboard, but can you do any tricks on it?

entries.meaning: An effective, clever or quick way of doing something.
examples: tricks of the trade;  what's the trick of getting this chair to fold up?

entries.meaning: Mischievous or annoying behavior; a prank.
examples: the tricks of boys
They played a crude trick on the teacher.

entries.meaning: (dated) A particular habit or manner; a peculiarity; a trait.
examples: a trick of drumming with the fingers; a trick of frowning

entries.meaning: A knot, braid, or plait of hair.
examples: I cannot tell , but it stirs me more than all your court curls , or your spangles , or your tricks

entries.meaning: (card games) A sequence in which each player plays a card and a winning play is determined.
examples: I was able to take the second trick with the queen of hearts.

entries.meaning: (slang) A sex act, chiefly one performed for payment; an act of prostitution.
examples: turn a trick
turn tricks

entries.meaning: (slang) A customer or client of a prostitute.
examples: Synonyms: john; see also Thesaurus:prostitute's client
As the businessman rounded the corner, she thought, "Here comes another trick."

entries.meaning: (slang, vulgar) A term of abuse.
A daily period of work, especially in shift-based jobs.
examples: Woodside Junction—On 8 hour basis, first trick $60, second trick $60, third trick $50.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A sailor's spell of work at the helm, usually two hours long.
A toy; a trifle; a plaything.

verbs.description: trick (third-person singular simple present tricks, present participle tricking, simple past and past participle tricked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fool; to cause to believe something untrue; to deceive.
examples: You tried to trick me when you said that house was underpriced.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) To draw (as opposed to blazon - to describe in words).
To dress; to decorate; to adorn fantastically; often followed by up, off, or out.
examples: Trick her off in air.
